description: From Latin effluvium (“an outlet”), from effluō (“flow out or away”), from ex (“out of, from”) + fluō (“flow”).

nouns.description: effluvium (countable and uncountable, plural effluvia or effluviums)

entries.meaning: A gaseous or vaporous emission, especially a foul-smelling one.
examples: And he breathed the breath of the house—a dank savour rather than a smell—a cold, musty effluvium as from underground vaults mingled with the reeking exhalations of linoleum and mildewed and rotten woodwork.

entries.meaning: A condition causing the shedding of hair.
